docs.lead_paragraph: The American beverage industry has introduced a number of new offerings catering to consumers, especially women, who want wholesome, low-alcohol choices.

headline.main: From Gluten-Free Beer to Kombucha, Alcohol Options for Health-Conscious Drinkers

docs.abstract: Beverage industry is rolling out a number of new products for health-conscious drinkers, including several gluten-free, low-calorie and low-alcohol options; trend follows growing discrimination among consumers, and is particularly aimed at capturing loyalty of female drinkers; new brands include Kombrucha, mixture of tea and beer that is sweetened with agave.
docs.snippet: The American beverage industry has introduced a number of new offerings catering to consumers, especially women, who want wholesome, low-alcohol choices.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sri Lanka's new health minister said a mystery kidney disease that has ravaged farmers in part of the country for two decades will be given top priority under the newly elected government.

headline.main: New Sri Lankan Health Minister Vows to Help Kidney Patients
headline.print_headline: New Sri Lankan Health Minister Vows to Help Kidney Patients

docs.snippet: Sri Lanka's new health minister said a mystery kidney disease that has ravaged farmers in part of the country for two decades will be given top priority under the newly elected government.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the past 50 years, meat has gotten less fatty and easier to chew — thanks in part to the U.S. Meat Animal Research Center. But the achievement has come at a steep cost to the lab’s animals.

headline.seo: Animal Welfare at Risk in Experiments for Meat Industry
headline.main: U.S. Research Lab Lets Livestock Suffer in Quest for Profit
headline.print_headline: In Quest for More Meat Profits, U.S. Lab Lets Animals Suffer

docs.abstract: US Meat Animal Research Center in Nebraska has re-engineered farm animals with several distinct market advantages, but changes have come at cruel cost for the animals; taxpayer-funded research has yielded less costly animals with more offspring and leaner and more plentiful meat, but many of them are born weakened and deformed, dying in huge numbers or living brief lives of intense suffering.
docs.snippet: In the past 50 years, meat has gotten less fatty and easier to chew — thanks in part to the U.S. Meat Animal Research Center. But the achievement has come at a steep cost to the lab’s animals.

docs.lead_paragraph: There are at least four crucial issues the president should mention in his speech that affect our health. But will he?

headline.main: Let’s Address the State of Food

docs.snippet: There are at least four crucial issues the president should mention in his speech that affect our health. But will he?

docs.lead_paragraph: Some wonder if a directive to hasten death by withholding “ordinary means of nutrition and hydration” should apply to a person who can’t remember it.

headline.main: Complexities of Choosing an End Game for Dementia
headline.print_headline: Complexities of Choosing an End Game for Dementia

docs.abstract: Ethicists, lawyers and older adults are engaged in debate over whether patients who develop dementia should be allowed to end their own lives via withdrawal of food and drink as specified in advance directive; at center of debate is whether a patient can choose to end their life after they become incapable of remembering decisions made while mentally competent.
docs.snippet: Some wonder if a directive to hasten death by withholding “ordinary means of nutrition and hydration” should apply to a person who can’t remember it.

keywords.value: Living Wills and Health Care Proxies
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Swiss food giant Nestle plans to invest about 1 billion Egyptian pounds ($137.93 million) in Egypt in the next few years and believes economic reforms could deliver results, its regional CEO said on Monday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania has agreed to pay $48.83 million to settle U.S. government claims it violated federal law by providing benefits to ineligible aliens under Medicaid and two other federal programs from 2004 to 2010.

headline.main: Pennsylvania to Pay U.S. $48.8 Million Over Benefits to Aliens
headline.print_headline: Pennsylvania to Pay U.S. $48.8 Million Over Benefits to Aliens
